About the BFA Program:The Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) in Fine Art is a cohort-based program for students in their junior and senior years.The degree is a 120-unit program requiring 70 units of courses in studio and art history, giving students the opportunity to develop a high level of expertise within their chosen concentration(s). The BFA is the degree of choice for students interested in pursuing graduate studies or other professional opportunities. The lower division coursework is designed to give students a solid technical foundation in studio art. Students at the upper division level focus their study in consultation with an advisor on approved elective courses in painting, drawing and illustration, jewelry and small metals, photography, ceramics, printmaking, sculpture, and digital media/graphic design. The upper division component is tailored to each student’s individual studio emphasis. Through problem-solving assignments and accompanying instruction, students learn processes and strategies for creating works of art in various media. By concentrating on a particular studio area in depth, students can prepare a portfolio for further professional opportunities or for postgraduate study. Note - students who wish to pursue a minor or second major in another field, should consult with an advisor and may find that the B.A. degree in Art with a concentration in Studio Art a more attractive option with greater flexibility.Admission Requirements & Procedures:Admission to the program is competitive. To be considered, an applicant must have completed the lower division core courses in the art major (15 units) and two lower division studio elective courses in the art studio concentration with a minimum GPA of 3.00 (B average). In addition, applicants are required to electronically submit images of their work, two academic references, a short personal statement and an unofficial transcript. Transfer students interested in the B.F.A. program may apply to the program following the above guidelines. Students must meet university admission requirements as well as the BFA admission requirements.For university transfer requirements, see the “Admission Information” section of the catalog.Please refer to the department website for the most current information regarding application guidelines, application forms and timelines: https://art.humboldt.edu/bfa-fine-arts

Students considering this major are strongly urged to review the University Catalog for further information about this major, the concentrations, emphases and other upper division course options. Many of the areas below are primarily composed of upper division coursework not reflected here on ASSIST, only lower division courses are published.Humboldt’s program is unique among the child development programs in that:core courses (which all students take) give cohesive and comprehensive attention to children’s development and socialization;an on-campus practicum is required;additional practicums with children or families are available in the emphasis areas;coursework beyond the core is based on the student’s own identified special interests.In core courses students learn basic principles and theories of child development as well as practices that support children and families. Students select one of the following three concentrations: Child and Family Services, Teaching or Specialized Studies. Within the first two concentrations, students also select an emphasis. The Specialized Studies concentration is individually designed between student and advisor.Important note for transfer students: Students may not use the same transferable course for both CD 253 and CD 255. Please select another course to meet the remaining courses required.

Additional grade and repeat information for ERE Majors: Grades of D, D+, F, WU, and NC count as failed attempts. Required courses in the major may not be repeated more than one time. If a student has two failed attempts in a required course, the student will not be able to graduate with an ERE degree.

All students in this major tailor their focus in the degree by choosing a suite of applied courses in one of the following five Emphasis Area options. The emphasis areas are designed to provide students with complementary skills in an applied field. Appropriate TechnologyCommunity Organizing - no lower division requirements to list below, see the catalog for detailsEcology & Conservation ScienceGeospatial AnalysisNote: students choosing this emphasis area should select GSP 101 & 101L from the Lower Division Core (instead of ESM 230). GSP 101 & 101L are prerequisites to other courses in this areaMedia ProductionImportant information for all emphasis areas: In the lower division core requirements, students choose between ESM 230-Environmental Methods or GSP 101 & 101L-Geospatial Concepts. Students choosing to take ESM 230 after transferring to Cal Poly Humboldt should be aware this course has a prerequisite of major course GEOG 106, as well as STAT 109 which is not required elsewhere in the major. See the Optional Prerequisite Courses section at the end of this agreement to view transferable courses which will meet this prerequisite.

majors.major: Leadership Studies [Interdisciplinary Studies B.A. - Leadership Studies Concentration]
general_titles: Leadership Studies at Humboldt State
general_texts: Cal Poly Humboldt's BA in Interdisciplinary Studies with a concentration in Leadership Studies is composed of upper division major courses. There are no lower division prerequisites for the courses in the major. The courses are 100% online. To learn more, contact the Department at https://extended.humboldt.edu/leadership-studies Preparation: This is a degree completion program designed for upper division transfer students and working adults who want to customize their learning experience to align with their current professional goals. An associates degree is NOT required to be admitted to the Leadership Studies major, although many applicants do have an associates degree prior to applying. To be admitted, applicants must complete -- before the application term -- at least 60 and up to 70 units of lower division coursework with at least a 2.0 cumulative grade point average based on their transferable work. Within those 60-70 units, they must complete at least 30 units of general education (GE) coursework with grades of C- or higher. As part of those 30 GE units, they must complete, with C- or better, all four of these subject areas: Written Communication (English Composition); Oral Communication (Public Speaking); Critical Thinking; and Mathematics/Quantitative Reasoning. For more information on how to apply: https://extended.humboldt.edu/leadership-studies/apply Fee Structure: Students pay per course instead of paying full time or part time tuition rates. Because the Leadership Studies Program is delivered by the College Extended Education & Global Engagement, students are not subject to HSU state fees. Self-support programs do not receive tax dollars from the State. Therefore, please be aware that State University Grants, Cal Grants and fee waivers cannot be applied to pay for this program. Federal Pell Grants and Federal Student Loans MAY be applied. For more information about the program cost, visit the resources above.

majors.major: Liberal Studies B.A. - Child Development/Elementary Education Concentration
general_titles: GENERAL INFORMATION ABOUT THIS MAJOR
general_texts: The Liberal Studies, B.A. has a core set of courses that focus on 21st century teaching approaches and emphasize the traditional disciplines taught in elementary schools. All students start out in one of the non-integrated concentrations and may be admitted to the integrated credential concentration in their junior or senior year at Humboldt State if they meet all admission requirements. The Integrated Teacher Education Program (ITEP) is a combined 4-year bachelor’s degree and credential program for students pursuing a teaching credential.Child Development/ Elementary Education Concentration Designed for students who wish to become elementary school teachers in grades K-6. Students take courses in traditional disciplines taught in elementary schools alongside courses focusing on developmental characteristics of children.The optional ITEP Concentration in this concentration allows undergraduate students to earn a bachelor’s degree, and to be recommended for a preliminary Special Education (i.e. Education Specialist) credential.Elementary Education ConcentrationPrepares students to work in a variety of careers within the field of education or enter a post-baccalaureate credential program. Student interest and career goals are central to selection of their individually designed depth of study coursework.The optional ITEP Concentration allows undergraduate students to earn a bachelor’s degree, and to be recommended for a preliminary Multiple Subject Credential.Students interested in the ITEP concentrations should refer to the University Catalog for current admission requirements. An overall GPA of 2.67 or above is required for admission to either of the ITEP concentrations.The Non-Integrated Pathway is available for students who wish to earn a bachelor's degree only.Note: Because the Liberal Studies teacher preparation emphases prepare students for a state licensed credential, requirements may be changed by state mandate at any time.

general_titles: Impaction Criteria for 2023-24 Applicants
ABOUT THIS major
general_texts:
During the 2023-2024 application cycle, this major is impacted for Upper Division Transfer applicants (60 or more semester units). Admission to certain majors at Cal Poly Humboldt is competitive because the campus continues to receive more qualified applicants than available new student spaces. Entrance into these programs is a selective and competitive process, and supplemental criteria may be used.


Students must apply during the priority application filing period (October 1 - November 30 for fall semester; August 1-31 for spring semester). Please refer to the Office of Admissions website for the most up to date information on impacted programs and supplemental admission criteria: https://admissions.humboldt.edu/apply/impaction

This is an RN to BSN program.The Nursing RN to BSN program at Cal Poly Humboldt is designed for students who have earned an associate degree in nursing, hold a Registered Nursing (RN) license, and want to advance their skills in leadership, care management and health promotion. The program’s curriculum is designed specifically for our area, focusing on physical and psychosocial health needs and problems within the region’s rural and tribal communities. The program accommodates working nurses with a flexible blend of online and in-person courses.Program Admission RequirementsTo be eligible for admission to the program, candidates must:be a graduate of a nationally recognized, regionally accredited associate degree program in nursinghave a current, clear, and active California Registered Nursing (RN) licensehave a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.75 from all transfer institutionshave completed the eight CSU systemwide nursing program prerequisites as outlined under Prerequisites to the Major belowmaintain current California R.N. licensure while enrolled in nursing coursesit is the student's responsibility to notify the program director immediately, in writing, of any changes in licensure statusLearn more at nursing.humboldt.edu/

Recreation Administration majors will complete an emphasis area as well as the Business Requirement.


Emphasis Areas

Choose one of the upper division emphasis areas below. Refer to the University Catalog for more information.


Diving Leadership Emphasis

Self-Designed Emphasis


Business Requirement

All Recreation Administration majors will also complete the Business Requirement - either complete a minor in business OR complete a minimum of 12 units of business and/or economics advisor-approved coursework. All business courses must be approved by an advisor. At least 8 units must be upper division.

general_titles: Admission to the BASW Program
general_texts: Information about the Bachelor of Arts in Social Work (BASW) program: To be eligible to register for junior-level courses in the Social Work major, students must have completed, or be in the process of completing, all prerequisites, with a 2.0 GPA in all social work courses is necessary to be fully accepted to the program. Lower division GE courses required for the major can be taken at a community college and can be taken CR/NC.Program faculty can advise students on courses preparing them for their transfer to Cal Poly Humboldt's Social Work Program. Contact socialwork@humboldt.edu for more information. Students missing one or more of these major prerequisites may still be eligible for admission to the university (check the Office of Admissions website for current requirements). These students will not be eligible to begin junior-level courses but will work with an advisor to complete the prerequisites during their first year at Cal Poly Humboldt and apply to join the BASW cohort the following fall semester.Fall Cohort: Major coursework (upper division level) always begins in Fall semester; students are advised to plan to transfer in a fall semester accordingly.

general_titles: About the Spanish Major
general_texts: Cal Poly Humboldt's Spanish B.A. Program is composed of upper division courses only. Preparation: A good background in English grammar and syntax is desirable. Previous Spanish study is welcomed but not required. Residency Abroad Requirement: Complete an approved academic semester program abroad in a Spanish-speaking region of the Hispanic World. Contact the department for further information: www.humboldt.edu/wlc
